// filepath: /Users/justin/Library/CloudStorage/Dropbox/NYU/Semester 2 ('25 Spring)/Sinetactophone/daisyduino/src/nano/main.cpp
const byte newAddresses[NUM_SENSORS] = {NEW_ADDRESS_0, NEW_ADDRESS_1, NEW_ADDRESS_2, NEW_ADDRESS_3, NEW_ADDRESS_4, NEW_ADDRESS_5};
const byte DEFAULT_ADDRESS = 0x29;const byte TCA_ADDRESS = 0x70;
// --- Global Objects ---
TCA9548 tca(TCA_ADDRESS);SparkFun_VL53L5CX myImagers[NUM_SENSORS];VL53L5CX_ResultsData measurementData;
// Helper function to select TCA channel
// Note: Rob Tillaart's selectChannel returns void. Error checking is less direct.
void selectChannel(uint8_t channel) {
  // Serial.println(channel);
  tca.selectChannel(channel);
  // We can't directly check for success here like with the Adafruit library.
  // Failure will likely manifest as subsequent sensor communication errors.
  delay(10);}

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  while (!Serial)
  Serial.println("Nano 33 IoT - TCA9548 (Rob Tillaart) & VL53L5CX Address Setting");

  Wire.begin();

  // Initialize Multiplexer
  Serial.println("Looking for TCA9548...");
  tca.begin();  if (!tca.isConnected()) {}
  Serial.println("TCA9548 found.");

  // --- Set Unique I2C Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nAttempting to set unique I2C addresses...");
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_SENSORS; i++) {
    uint8_t channel = sensorChannels[i];
    byte newAddr = newAddresses[i];

    Serial.print("Checking/Setting Sensor on Channel ");
    Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" to Address 0x");
    Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel);    delay(50);
    // Check if sensor is ALREADY at the new address
    Wire.beginTransmission(newAddr);
    byte error = Wire.endTransmission();

    if (error == 0) {} else {

        for (byte scanAddr = 1; scanAddr < 127; scanAddr++) {}

        // Process scan results
        if (devicesFound == 1) {
            // Exactly one device found, assume it's our sensor at foundAddr
            Serial.print("  Attempting begin() at found address 0x");
            Serial.println(foundAddr, HEX);
            if (myImagers[i].begin(foundAddr) == false) {                continue;            }
            Serial.println("  Sensor initialized at found address.");

            // Now, set the new address
            Serial.print("  Setting new address to 0x");
            Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);
            if (myImagers[i].setAddress(newAddr) == false) {
                delay(5000);
                continue; // Go to the next channel
            }
            Serial.println("  New address set successfully.");
            delay(50); // Give sensor time to process address change

        } else if (devicesFound == 0) {
            Serial.println("  No sensor found on this channel during scan. Skipping channel.");
            delay(5000);
            continue; // Go to the next channel
        } else { // devicesFound > 1 - Should not happen with one sensor per channel
            Serial.println("  Multiple devices found on this channel during scan! Check wiring. Skipping channel.");
            delay(5000);
            continue; // Go to the next channel
        }
    }
  }
  Serial.println("Address setting phase complete.");


  // --- Initialize Sensors with NEW Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nInitializing sensors with their assigned addresses...");
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_SENSORS; i++) {
    uint8_t channel = sensorChannels[i];
    byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i]; // Use the NEW address

    Serial.print("Initializing Sensor "); Serial.print(i);
    Serial.print(" on Channel "); Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" at Address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel); // Select the channel

    // Initialize the persistent sensor object using its NEW address
    if (myImagers[i].begin(currentAddr) == false) {
        Serial.print("  Failed to initialize Sensor "); Serial.print(i);
        Serial.print(" at address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);
        Serial.println("  Check wiring/address setting. Freezing...");
        while(1);
    }
    Serial.println("  Sensor initialized.");

    // Configure and start ranging
    myImagers[i].setResolution(SENSOR_RESOLUTION);
    myImagers[i].setRangingFrequency(RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ);
    myImagers[i].startRanging();
    Serial.print("  Sensor "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(" ranging started.");
  }

  Serial.println("\n--- Setup Complete ---");
}

void loop() {
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_SENSORS; i++) {
    uint8_t channel = sensorChannels[i];
    byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i]; // Sensor's assigned address

    // Select the channel for the sensor we want to check
    selectChannel(channel);

    // Check if data is ready for the current sensor
    // The object myImagers[i] is already configured for its unique address
    if (myImagers[i].isDataReady()) {
      // Get the data
      if (myImagers[i].getRangingData(&measurementData)) {
        Serial.print("\n--- Sensor ");
        Serial.print(i);
        Serial.print(" (Ch:"); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.print("/Addr:0x"); Serial.print(currentAddr, HEX);
        Serial.println(") ---");
        Serial.println("Distance (mm):");

        // Iterate through each zone (pixel)
        for (int j = 0; j < SENSOR_RESOLUTION; j++) {
          Serial.print(measurementData.distance_mm[j]);
          Serial.print("\t"); // Tab spacing

          // Newline after each row
          if ((j + 1) % IMAGE_WIDTH == 0) {
            Serial.println();
          }
        }
      } else {
          Serial.print("Error getting data from Sensor ");
          Serial.println(i);
      }
    }
  }
  // Add a small delay outside the sensor loop if readings are too fast
  delay(50); // Read all sensors approx every 50ms + processing time
}

message.text: Explain what the 16 different readouts for each sensor represent

parts.text: Explain what the 16 different readouts for each sensor represent

response.value:
The 16 values printed for each sensor (labeled `s{i}z0` through `s{i}z15`) represent the distance measurements from the 16 individual zones of that specific VL53L5CX sensor.

Here's the breakdown:

1.  **VL53L5CX Sensor:** This type of sensor is a Time-of-Flight (ToF) ranging sensor. Unlike simple distance sensors, it has an array of zones that can measure distances independently.
2.  **Resolution:** In your code,

is set to 16. This configures the sensor to operate in a **4x4 grid mode**.
3.  **16 Zones:** This 4x4 grid results in 16 distinct measurement zones.
4.  **
Array:** The SparkFun library stores the distance readings from these 16 zones sequentially in the
array. The index
(from 0 to 15) in the

corresponds to each of these zones.
5.  **Output:** Your code iterates through these 16 zones (`for (int j = 0; j < SENSOR_RESOLUTION; j++)`) and prints each distance value in millimeters using the Teleplot format `>s{sensor_index}z{zone_index}:{distance_value}`.

So, `>s0z0:150` means sensor 0, zone 0 measured a distance of 150mm. `>s0z15:160` means sensor 0, zone 15 measured 160mm, and so on for all 16 zones of each configured sensor.

// filepath: /Users/justin/Library/CloudStorage/Dropbox/NYU/Semester 2 ('25 Spring)/Sinetactophone/daisyduino/src/nano/main.cpp
const byte newAddresses[MAX_SENSORS] = {
    NEW_ADDRESS_0, NEW_ADDRESS_1, NEW_ADDRESS_2, NEW_ADDRESS_3,
    NEW_ADDRESS_4, NEW_ADDRESS_5, NEW_ADDRESS_6, NEW_ADDRESS_7
};
const byte DEFAULT_ADDRESS = 0x29;const byte TCA_ADDRESS = 0x70;
// --- Global Objects ---
TCA9548 tca(TCA_ADDRESS);// Size arrays for the maximum possible sensors
SparkFun_VL53L5CX myImagers[MAX_SENSORS];
VL53L5CX_ResultsData measurementData;bool sensorConfigured[MAX_SENSORS] = {false};
// Helper function to select TCA channel
// Note: Rob Tillaart's selectChannel returns void. Error checking is less direct.
void selectChannel(uint8_t channel) {
  delay(10);}

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  while (!Serial)
  Serial.println("Nano 33 IoT - TCA9548 (Rob Tillaart) & VL53L5CX Address Setting");

  Wire.begin();

  // Initialize Multiplexer
  Serial.println("Looking for TCA9548...");
  tca.begin();  if (!tca.isConnected()) {}
  Serial.println("TCA9548 found.");

  // --- Set Unique I2C Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nAttempting to set unique I2C addresses...");
  // Iterate through all channels defined in sensorChannels
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK; i++) {
    if (channel >= MAX_SENSORS) {
        continue;
    }
    byte newAddr = newAddresses[channel];
    Serial.print("Checking/Setting Sensor on Channel ");
    Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" to Address 0x");
    Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel);    delay(50);
    // Check if sensor is ALREADY at the new address
    Wire.beginTransmission(newAddr);
    byte error = Wire.endTransmission();

    if (error == 0) {} else {

        for (byte scanAddr = 1; scanAddr < 127; scanAddr++) {}

        // Process scan results
        if (devicesFound == 1) {
            Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);
            // Use channel index for myImagers array
            if (myImagers[channel].setAddress(newAddr) == false) {
                continue;
            }
            Serial.println("  New address set successfully.");
            sensorConfigured[channel] = true;            delay(50);

        } else if (devicesFound == 0) {
            continue;
        } else {
            continue;
        }
    }
  }
  Serial.println("Address setting phase complete.");


  // --- Initialize Sensors with NEW Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nInitializing sensors with their assigned addresses...");
  // Iterate through all potential sensor slots (0 to MAX_SENSORS-1)
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // Only proceed if this sensor slot was successfully configured
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
        uint8_t channel = i; // Channel index matches the loop index 'i' here
        byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i];

        Serial.print("Initializing Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
        Serial.print(" (Channel "); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.print(") at Address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);

        selectChannel(channel);
        delay(50);

        // Initialize the persistent sensor object using its NEW address
        if (myImagers[i].begin(currentAddr) == false) {
            Serial.print("  Failed to initialize Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
            Serial.print(" at address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);
            Serial.println("  Marking as unconfigured and skipping.");
            sensorConfigured[i] = false; // Mark as failed
            continue;
        }
        Serial.println("  Sensor initialized.");
        myImagers[i].setResolution(SENSOR_RESOLUTION);
        myImagers[i].setRangingFrequency(RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ);
        myImagers[i].startRanging();
        Serial.print("  Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(" ranging started.");

    } else {
        // This slot wasn't configured, skip it silently or add a message if needed
        // Serial.print("Skipping initialization for Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
        // Serial.println(" (not configured).");
    }
  }

  Serial.println("\n--- Setup Complete ---");
}

void loop() {
  // Iterate through all potential sensor slots (0 to MAX_SENSORS-1)
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // Only read from sensors that were successfully configured
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
        uint8_t channel = i; // Channel index matches the loop index 'i'
        byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i];

        selectChannel(channel);

        // Check if data is ready for the current sensor
        // Add a small delay before checking data readiness, might help stability
        delay(1);
        if (myImagers[i].isDataReady()) {
          // Get the data
          if (myImagers[i].getRangingData(&measurementData)) {
            // Print a minimal header for readability (optional)
            // Serial.print("\n--- Sensor slot ");
            // Serial.print(i);
            // Serial.print(" (Ch:"); Serial.print(channel);
            // Serial.print("/Addr:0x"); Serial.print(currentAddr, HEX);
            // Serial.println(") ---");

            // Iterate through each zone (pixel) and print in Teleplot format
            for (int j = 0; j < SENSOR_RESOLUTION; j++) {
              Serial.print(">s"); // Teleplot variable prefix
              Serial.print(i);    // Sensor index
              Serial.print("z");  // Zone separator
              Serial.print(j);    // Zone index
              Serial.print(":");  // Teleplot value separator
              Serial.println(measurementData.distance_mm[j]); // The distance value
            }
          } else {
              // Error getting data
              Serial.print("!ERR: Sensor slot "); // Use !ERR prefix for errors
              Serial.print(i);
              Serial.println(" getRangingData failed");
          }
        }
        // else {
            // Optional: Indicate if data wasn't ready for a configured sensor
            // Serial.print("!WARN: Sensor slot ");
            // Serial.print(i);
            // Serial.println(" data not ready");
        // }
    }
  }
  // Add a small delay outside the sensor loop if readings are too fast
  // Consider the time taken by reading all sensors and printing data.
  // If RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ is 15Hz (approx 66ms per sensor),
  // reading 8 sensors might take ~530ms. A small delay might be okay,
  // but a large one could cause missed readings.
  delay(10); // Reduced delay, adjust as needed based on performance
}
```

<userPrompt>
Explain what the 16 different readouts for each sensor represent
</userPrompt>

messages.content: Explain what the 16 different readouts for each sensor represent

The 16 values printed for each sensor (labeled `s{i}z0` through `s{i}z15`) represent the distance measurements from the 16 individual zones of that specific VL53L5CX sensor.

Here's the breakdown:

1.  **VL53L5CX Sensor:** This type of sensor is a Time-of-Flight (ToF) ranging sensor. Unlike simple distance sensors, it has an array of zones that can measure distances independently.
2.  **Resolution:** In your code, `SENSOR_RESOLUTION` is set to 16. This configures the sensor to operate in a **4x4 grid mode**.
3.  **16 Zones:** This 4x4 grid results in 16 distinct measurement zones.
4.  **`measurementData.distance_mm` Array:** The SparkFun library stores the distance readings from these 16 zones sequentially in the `measurementData.distance_mm` array. The index `j` (from 0 to 15) in the `loop()` corresponds to each of these zones.
5.  **Output:** Your code iterates through these 16 zones (`for (int j = 0; j < SENSOR_RESOLUTION; j++)`) and prints each distance value in millimeters using the Teleplot format `>s{sensor_index}z{zone_index}:{distance_value}`.

So, `>s0z0:150` means sensor 0, zone 0 measured a distance of 150mm. `>s0z15:160` means sensor 0, zone 15 measured 160mm, and so on for all 16 zones of each configured sensor.

Okay, the current format `>s{i}_zones:value0 value1 ... value15` is already suitable for multi-series charts in Teleplot. Each `s{i}_zones` variable will appear as a single plot containing 16 series (one for each zone).

To make the updates faster, we can do two things:

1.  **Increase the Sensor's Ranging Frequency:** The VL53L5CX can range faster when using 4x4 resolution (up to 60Hz).
2.  **Reduce Delays in the Code:** Remove unnecessary delays in the main loop.

Let's apply these changes:

**1. Increase Ranging Frequency:**

response.value:
Okay, I've increased the sensor's ranging frequency to 60Hz, which is the maximum for the 4x4 resolution you're using. This should make the sensor itself capture data faster.

Now, let's restructure the

function to group the data by zone index for multi-series plotting in Teleplot and remove the final delay.

```cpp

near the top of the file.
2.  **Two-Pass Loop:**
    *   **Pass 1 (Data Acquisition):** The first `for` loop iterates through all potential sensor slots (0-7). If a sensor is configured, it selects the channel, checks if data is ready, and if so, reads the data using `getRangingData()` into a dedicated spot in the `allSensorData` array (`allSensorData[i]`). A flag `sensorReadOK[i]` tracks if the read was successful for this specific loop iteration.
    *   **Pass 2 (Data Printing):** The second part loops through each *zone index*
(0-15). For each zone, it prints the Teleplot variable name (`>z0:`, `>z1:`, etc.). Then, an inner loop goes through all sensor slots
(0-7). If that sensor
is configured AND its data was read successfully in Pass 1 (`sensorReadOK[i]`), it prints the distance value for the current zone

from that sensor's stored data (`allSensorData[i].distance_mm[j]`), followed by a space. This builds up a line containing the readings for one specific zone across all successfully read sensors.
3.  **Removed Loop Delay:** The
at the very end of the

function has been removed to allow the loop to run as fast as possible, limited only by the sensor reading time and serial printing time.

The output will now look like this (assuming sensors 0, 1, 2 are configured and read successfully):

```
>z0:150 180 200
>z1:155 182 205
>z2:152 181 202
...
>z15:160 185 210
```

In Teleplot, this will create variables `z0`, `z1`, ... `z15`. Each variable will contain multiple series (one for each sensor that reported data), allowing you to visualize how the distance for a specific zone changes across different sensors simultaneously.

  Serial.println("\nAttempting to set unique I2C addresses...");
  // Iterate through all channels defined in sensorChannels
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK; i++) {
    if (channel >= MAX_SENSORS) {
        continue;
    }
    byte newAddr = newAddresses[channel];
    Serial.print("Checking/Setting Sensor on Channel ");
    Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" to Address 0x");
    Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel);    delay(50);
    // Check if sensor is ALREADY at the new address
    Wire.beginTransmission(newAddr);
    byte error = Wire.endTransmission();

    if (error == 0) {} else {

        for (byte scanAddr = 1; scanAddr < 127; scanAddr++) {}

                continue;
            }
            Serial.println("  Sensor initialized at found address.");

            Serial.print("  Setting new address to 0x");
            Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);
            // Use channel index for myImagers array
            if (myImagers[channel].setAddress(newAddr) == false) {
                continue;
            }
            Serial.println("  New address set successfully.");
            sensorConfigured[channel] = true;            delay(50);

        } else if (devicesFound == 0) {
            continue;
        } else {
            // sensorConfigured[channel] remains false
            delay(5000);
            continue;
        }
    }
  }
  Serial.println("Address setting phase complete.");


  // --- Initialize Sensors with NEW Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nInitializing sensors with their assigned addresses...");
  // Iterate through all potential sensor slots (0 to MAX_SENSORS-1)
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // Only proceed if this sensor slot was successfully configured
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
        uint8_t channel = i; // Channel index matches the loop index 'i' here
        byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i];

        Serial.print(" (Channel "); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.print(") at Address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);

        selectChannel(channel);
        delay(50);

        // Initialize the persistent sensor object using its NEW address
        if (myImagers[i].begin(currentAddr) == false) {
            Serial.print("  Failed to initialize Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
            Serial.print(" at address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);

            sensorConfigured[i] = false; // Mark as failed

  Serial.println("\n--- Setup Complete ---");
}

void loop() {
  // Iterate through all potential sensor slots (0 to MAX_SENSORS-1)
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // Only read from sensors that were successfully configured
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
        uint8_t channel = i; // Channel index matches the loop index 'i'

    }
  }
  // Adjust delay as needed
  delay(10);
}

Okay, the current format `>s{i}_zones:value0 value1 ... value15` is already suitable for multi-series charts in Teleplot. Each `s{i}_zones` variable will appear as a single plot containing 16 series (one for each zone).

To make the updates faster, we can do two things:

1.  **Increase the Sensor's Ranging Frequency:** The VL53L5CX can range faster when using 4x4 resolution (up to 60Hz).
2.  **Reduce Delays in the Code:** Remove unnecessary delays in the main loop.

Let's apply these changes:

**1. Increase Ranging Frequency:**

I'll change the `RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ` constant.

parts.text: Is there a delay in sending serial data?

response.value:
Yes, there are a couple of factors that introduce delays related to sending serial data in your code:

1.  **Serial Transmission Time (Implicit Delay):**
    *   You are sending a considerable amount of data over serial in each loop (potentially `>sX_zones:` + 16 numbers + spaces + newline for *each* active sensor).
    *   Serial communication at a fixed baud rate (115200 bps in your case) takes time.
and

write data to a transmit buffer. If you try to write data faster than the hardware can send it over the wire, these functions will **block** (pause your code execution) until there is space in the buffer.
    *   Given the amount of data per sensor and the number of sensors, this blocking behavior is the most significant implicit delay related to serial sending. It effectively limits how fast your

can run, regardless of the sensor speed.

2.  **Explicit

:**
    *   You have a
at the very end of your

. While not directly part of the serial *sending* mechanism, it adds an explicit 10ms pause to every loop cycle *after* all serial data for that cycle has been queued (or sent, if blocking occurred).

In summary, while there isn't a specific delay *command* just for serial sending, the act of sending a large volume of data at 115200 baud inherently takes time and will cause
/`println()` to block, creating delays in your loop execution.

Is there a delay in sending serial data?

messages.content: Is there a delay in sending serial data?

Yes, there are a couple of factors that introduce delays related to sending serial data in your code:

1.  **Serial Transmission Time (Implicit Delay):**
    *   You are sending a considerable amount of data over serial in each loop (potentially `>sX_zones:` + 16 numbers + spaces + newline for *each* active sensor).
    *   Serial communication at a fixed baud rate (115200 bps in your case) takes time. `Serial.print()` and `Serial.println()` write data to a transmit buffer. If you try to write data faster than the hardware can send it over the wire, these functions will **block** (pause your code execution) until there is space in the buffer.
    *   Given the amount of data per sensor and the number of sensors, this blocking behavior is the most significant implicit delay related to serial sending. It effectively limits how fast your `loop()` can run, regardless of the sensor speed.

2.  **Explicit `delay(10)`:**
    *   You have a `delay(10)` at the very end of your `loop()`. While not directly part of the serial *sending* mechanism, it adds an explicit 10ms pause to every loop cycle *after* all serial data for that cycle has been queued (or sent, if blocking occurred).

In summary, while there isn't a specific delay *command* just for serial sending, the act of sending a large volume of data at 115200 baud inherently takes time and will cause `Serial.print()`/`println()` to block, creating delays in your loop execution.

Okay, integrating a different sensor type like the VL53L0X requires adding its library and handling it specifically in the setup and loop.

**1. Add Library Dependency:**

First, you need to tell PlatformIO to include the Adafruit VL53L0X library. Add the following line under the `lib_deps` section in your

file:

```ini
[env:...]
; ... other settings ...
lib_deps =
    ; ... other libraries ...
    sparkfun/SparkFun VL53L5CX Imager @ ^1.2.8
    robtillaart/TCA9548 @ ^0.3.0
    adafruit/Adafruit VL53L0X @ ^1.2.0  ; <-- Add this line
```

Make sure to rebuild the project after editing

so PlatformIO downloads the library.

It looks like the Adafruit VL53L0X library isn't installed in your PlatformIO project. Please install it using the PlatformIO Library Manager. You can typically do this:

1.  Open the PlatformIO sidebar in VS Code.
2.  Go to "Libraries".
3.  Search for "Adafruit VL53L0X".
4.  Click on the library and choose "Add to Project", selecting your `daisyduino` environment.

Once the library is installed, the `#include <Adafruit_VL53L0X.h>` line should work.

After you've installed the library, I can proceed with adding the code to handle the VL53L0X sensor on channel 5 alongside the others. I'll need to:

1.  Define a constant for the VL53L0X channel (5).
2.  Create a global `Adafruit_VL53L0X` object.
3.  Add a boolean flag to track if the VL53L0X was successfully configured.
4.  Modify the

function to handle the VL53L0X differently during address checking (it uses a fixed address) and initialization.
5.  Modify the

function to read from the VL53L0X using its specific methods and print its single distance reading in a Teleplot-compatible format.

Let me know when you've installed the library, and I'll provide the code changes.

// filepath: /Users/justin/Library/CloudStorage/Dropbox/NYU/Semester 2 ('25 Spring)/Sinetactophone/daisyduino/src/nano/main.cpp
void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  while (!Serial);
  Serial.println("Nano 33 IoT - TCA9548 (Rob Tillaart) & VL53L5CX Address Setting");

  Wire.begin();

  // Initialize Multiplexer
  Serial.println("Looking for TCA9548...");
  tca.begin(); // Initialize the multiplexer object
  if (!tca.isConnected()) { // Check if the multiplexer is detected
    Serial.print("TCA9548 not found at address 0x");
    Serial.println(TCA_ADDRESS, HEX);
    Serial.println("Check wiring. Freezing...");
    while (1);
  }
  Serial.println("TCA9548 found.");

  // --- Set Unique I2C Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nAttempting to set unique I2C addresses...");
  // Iterate through all channels defined in sensorChannels
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK; i++) {
    uint8_t channel = sensorChannels[i];
    // Check if channel index is valid before accessing newAddresses
    if (channel >= MAX_SENSORS) {
        Serial.print("Error: Channel index "); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.println(" is out of bounds for address array. Skipping.");
        continue;
    }
    byte newAddr = newAddresses[channel]; // Use channel index to get target address

    Serial.print("Checking/Setting Sensor on Channel ");
    Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" to Address 0x");
    Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel); // Select the channel
    delay(50); // Delay AFTER selecting channel

    // Check if sensor is ALREADY at the new address
    Wire.beginTransmission(newAddr);
    byte error = Wire.endTransmission();

    if (error == 0) {
        Serial.println("  Sensor already at target address.");
        sensorConfigured[channel] = true; // Mark this channel slot as configured
    } else {
        // Sensor not at target address. Scan the current channel to find it.
        Serial.println("  Sensor not at target address. Scanning channel...");
        byte foundAddr = 0;
        int devicesFound = 0;

        for (byte scanAddr = 1; scanAddr < 127; scanAddr++) {
            if (scanAddr == newAddr) continue; // Skip target address

            Wire.beginTransmission(scanAddr);
            byte scanError = Wire.endTransmission();

            if (scanError == 0) {
                Serial.print("    Found device at address 0x");
                Serial.println(scanAddr, HEX);
                devicesFound++;
                foundAddr = scanAddr;
                break; // Assume only one sensor per channel
            } else if (scanError != 2) {
                Serial.print("    Scan error "); Serial.print(scanError);
                Serial.print(" at address 0x"); Serial.println(scanAddr, HEX);
            }
            delay(2);
        }

        // Process scan results
        if (devicesFound == 1) {
            Serial.print("  Attempting begin() at found address 0x");
            Serial.println(foundAddr, HEX);
            // Use channel index for myImagers array
            if (myImagers[channel].begin(foundAddr) == false) {
                Serial.println("  Failed to initialize sensor at found address. Skipping channel.");
                delay(5000);
                continue;
            }
            Serial.println("  Sensor initialized at found address.");

            Serial.print("  Setting new address to 0x");
            Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);
            // Use channel index for myImagers array
            if (myImagers[channel].setAddress(newAddr) == false) {
                Serial.println("  Failed to set new I2C address. Skipping channel.");
                delay(5000);
                continue;
            }
            Serial.println("  New address set successfully.");
            sensorConfigured[channel] = true; // Mark this channel slot as configured
            delay(50);

        } else if (devicesFound == 0) {
            Serial.println("  No sensor found on this channel during scan. Skipping channel.");
            // sensorConfigured[channel] remains false
            delay(5000); // Optional delay if no sensor found
            continue;
        } else {
            Serial.println("  Multiple devices found on this channel! Check wiring. Skipping channel.");
            // sensorConfigured[channel] remains false
            delay(5000);
            continue;
        }
    }
  }
  Serial.println("Address setting phase complete.");


  // --- Initialize Sensors with NEW Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nInitializing sensors with their assigned addresses...");
  // Iterate through all potential sensor slots (0 to MAX_SENSORS-1)
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // Only proceed if this sensor slot was successfully configured
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
        uint8_t channel = i; // Channel index matches the loop index 'i' here
        byte currentAddr = newAddresses[i];

        Serial.print("Initializing Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
        Serial.print(" (Channel "); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.print(") at Address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);

        selectChannel(channel);
        delay(50);

        // Initialize the persistent sensor object using its NEW address
        if (myImagers[i].begin(currentAddr) == false) {
            Serial.print("  Failed to initialize Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
            Serial.print(" at address 0x"); Serial.println(currentAddr, HEX);
            Serial.println("  Marking as unconfigured and skipping.");
            sensorConfigured[i] = false;            continue;
        }
        Serial.println("  Sensor initialized.");
        myImagers[i].setResolution(SENSOR_RESOLUTION);
        myImagers[i].setRangingFrequency(RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ);
        myImagers[i].startRanging();
        Serial.print("  Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(" ranging started.");

    } else {
        // This slot wasn't configured, skip it silently or add a message if needed
        // Serial.print("Skipping initialization for Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i);
    }
  }

  Serial.println("\n--- Setup Complete ---");
}

    adafruit/Adafruit VL53L0X @ ^1.2.0  ; <-- Add this line
```

// filepath: /Users/justin/Library/CloudStorage/Dropbox/NYU/Semester 2 ('25 Spring)/Sinetactophone/daisyduino/src/nano/main.cpp
// I2C Scanner Sketch
// Scans the I2C bus for devices and reports their addresses.

#include <Arduino.h>
#include <Wire.h>
#include "SparkFun_VL53L5CX_Library.h" // VL53L5CX library
#include "TCA9548.h"                   // Multiplexer library (Rob Tillaart)
#include <Adafruit_VL53L0X.h>          // VL53L0X library

// --- Configuration ---
const int NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK = 8; // Check all 8 channels of the TCA9548A
const int MAX_SENSORS = 8; // Maximum possible sensors we might configure arrays for
const int SENSOR_RESOLUTION = 16; // 4x4 = 16 zones
// const int SENSOR_RESOLUTION = 64; // 8x8 = 64 zones
const int IMAGE_WIDTH = (SENSOR_RESOLUTION == 16) ? 4 : 8;
const int RANGING_FREQUENCY_HZ = 60; // Max 15Hz for 8x8, 60Hz for 4x4 (Increased to 60Hz)

// Define the multiplexer channels to check.
// We'll iterate through these indices. If you only have 6 sensors,
// the code will skip channels where no sensor is found.
// You can customize this array later if you skip specific hardware ports.
const uint8_t sensorChannels[NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK] = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7};

// Define new unique I2C addresses to potentially assign for each channel slot
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_0 = 0x30;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_1 = 0x31;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_2 = 0x32;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_3 = 0x33;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_4 = 0x34;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_5 = 0x35;
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_6 = 0x36; // Address for channel 6 slot
const byte NEW_ADDRESS_7 = 0x37; // Address for channel 7 slot
const byte newAddresses[MAX_SENSORS] = {
    NEW_ADDRESS_0, NEW_ADDRESS_1, NEW_ADDRESS_2, NEW_ADDRESS_3,
    NEW_ADDRESS_4, NEW_ADDRESS_5, NEW_ADDRESS_6, NEW_ADDRESS_7
};
const byte DEFAULT_ADDRESS = 0x29; // Default address of the VL53L5CX
const byte TCA_ADDRESS = 0x70; // Default address for TCA9548A

// --- Global Objects ---
TCA9548 tca(TCA_ADDRESS);             // Multiplexer object (Rob Tillaart)
// Size arrays for the maximum possible sensors
SparkFun_VL53L5CX myImagers[MAX_SENSORS];
VL53L5CX_ResultsData measurementData;        // Structure for sensor results (reused)
bool sensorConfigured[MAX_SENSORS] = {false}; // Track configuration status for each channel slot

// Specific setup for VL53L0X on channel 5
const int VL53L0X_CHANNEL = 5;
Adafruit_VL53L0X lox = Adafruit_VL53L0X();
bool vl53l0xConfigured = false;

// Helper function to select TCA channel
// Note: Rob Tillaart's selectChannel returns void. Error checking is less direct.
void selectChannel(uint8_t channel) {
  if (channel >= 8) {
    Serial.print("Error: Invalid TCA channel ");
    Serial.println(channel);
    return; // Exit if channel is invalid
  }
  // Serial.print("Selecting TCA channel "); // Uncomment for verbose debugging
  // Serial.println(channel);
  tca.selectChannel(channel);
  // We can't directly check for success here like with the Adafruit library.
  // Failure will likely manifest as subsequent sensor communication errors.
  delay(10); // Increased delay after switching channel
}

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  while (!Serial);
  Serial.println("Nano 33 IoT - TCA9548 (Rob Tillaart) & VL53L5CX Address Setting");

  Wire.begin();

  // Initialize Multiplexer
  Serial.println("Looking for TCA9548...");
  tca.begin(); // Initialize the multiplexer object
  if (!tca.isConnected()) { // Check if the multiplexer is detected
    Serial.print("TCA9548 not found at address 0x");
    Serial.println(TCA_ADDRESS, HEX);
    Serial.println("Check wiring. Freezing...");
    while (1);
  }
  Serial.println("TCA9548 found.");

  // --- Set Unique I2C Addresses ---
  Serial.println("\nAttempting to set unique I2C addresses...");
  // Iterate through all channels defined in sensorChannels
  for (int i = 0; i < NUM_CHANNELS_TO_CHECK; i++) {
    uint8_t channel = sensorChannels[i];
    // Check if channel index is valid before accessing newAddresses
    if (channel >= MAX_SENSORS) {
        Serial.print("Error: Channel index "); Serial.print(channel);
        Serial.println(" is out of bounds for address array. Skipping.");
        continue;
    }
    byte newAddr = newAddresses[channel]; // Use channel index to get target address

    Serial.print("Checking/Setting Sensor on Channel ");
    Serial.print(channel);
    Serial.print(" to Address 0x");
    Serial.println(newAddr, HEX);

    selectChannel(channel); // Select the channel
    delay(50); // Delay AFTER selecting channel

    // Check if sensor is ALREADY at the new address
    Wire.beginTransmission(newAddr);
    byte error = Wire.endTransmission();

    if (error == 0) {
        Serial.println("  Sensor already at target address.");
        sensorConfigured[channel] = true; // Mark this channel slot as configured
    } else {
      // --- Special handling for VL53L0X on its dedicated channel ---
      if (channel == VL53L0X_CHANNEL) {
        Serial.println("  Checking for VL53L0X...");
        // VL53L0X always uses address 0x29 and doesn't support setAddress
        Wire.beginTransmission(DEFAULT_ADDRESS);
        error = Wire.endTransmission();
        if (error == 0) {
          Serial.println("    VL53L0X detected at default address.");
          // We don't set sensorConfigured[channel] because it's not a VL53L5CX
          // We will use vl53l0xConfigured flag later during initialization
        } else {
          Serial.println("    VL53L0X not found at default address.");
        }
        continue; // Skip the rest of the VL53L5CX logic for this channel
      }
      // --- End of special handling for VL53L0X ---

        // Sensor not at target address. Scan the current channel to find it.
        Serial.println("  Sensor not at target address. Scanning channel...");
        byte foundAddr = 0;
        int devicesFound = 0;

        for (byte scanAddr = 1; scanAddr < 127; scanAddr++) {
            if (scanAddr == newAddr) continue; // Skip target address

            Wire.beginTransmission(scanAddr);
            byte scanError = Wire.endTransmission();

            if (scanError == 0) {
                Serial.print("    Found device at address 0x");
                Serial.println(scanAddr, HEX);
                devicesFound++;
                foundAddr = scanAddr;
                break;            } else if (scanError != 2) {}
            delay(2);
        }

        // Process scan results
        if (devicesFound == 1) {
            Serial.print("  Attempting begin() at found address 0x");
            Serial.println(foundAddr, HEX);

        } else
    }
  }
}
```

response.value: Okay, that confirms the freeze happens exactly when the code tries to communicate with the sensor on channel 4 via

.

This almost certainly means there's an I2C communication problem specifically on that channel, and the microcontroller is getting stuck waiting for a response that never comes (or waiting for the I2C bus lines to be released). The most common causes are:

1.  **Faulty Sensor on Channel 4:** The sensor itself might be damaged or malfunctioning, causing it to lock up the I2C bus when addressed.
2.  **Wiring Problem for Channel 4:** A bad solder joint, loose connection, or short circuit on the SDA or SCL lines specifically for the sensor connected to channel 4.

**Recommended Next Steps (Hardware Troubleshooting):**

1.  **Power Down:** Turn off power to the Nano and sensors.
2.  **Inspect Wiring:** Carefully re-inspect the VCC, GND, SDA, and SCL connections for the sensor plugged into the multiplexer's channel 4 port. Ensure they are secure and not shorting against anything.
3.  **Swap Sensors:** The best test is to **swap** the physical sensor currently connected to channel 4 with a sensor from another channel that you know was working correctly (e.g., swap the sensors connected to channel 3 and channel 4).
4.  **Power Up and Test:** Turn the power back on and run the code again.
    *   **If the freeze now happens when trying to read channel 3:** This strongly indicates the sensor *originally* on channel 4 is faulty.
    *   **If the freeze *still* happens when trying to read channel 4 (even with the known good sensor):** This suggests a problem with the multiplexer's channel 4 port itself, or the wiring *between* the multiplexer and the Nano related to that channel (less likely if other channels work fine).

**Temporary Code Workaround (If needed):**

If you want to get the other sensors running while you troubleshoot the hardware, I can modify the code to completely skip trying to read channel 4. Let me know if you'd like to do that.

  } else if (vl53l0xConfigured && !vl53l0xReadOK) {}

  Serial.println("--- Loop End ---"); // Debug: Confirm loop end is reached
  // No delay at the end of the loop
}

messages.content:
It freezes after:

```
Debug: Attempting read from VL53L5CX (Channel 4)
Debug: selectChannel(4) completed.
Debug: Calling isDataReady() for channel 4
```

Okay, that confirms the freeze happens exactly when the code tries to communicate with the sensor on channel 4 via `myImagers[4].isDataReady()`.

This almost certainly means there's an I2C communication problem specifically on that channel, and the microcontroller is getting stuck waiting for a response that never comes (or waiting for the I2C bus lines to be released). The most common causes are:

1.  **Faulty Sensor on Channel 4:** The sensor itself might be damaged or malfunctioning, causing it to lock up the I2C bus when addressed.
2.  **Wiring Problem for Channel 4:** A bad solder joint, loose connection, or short circuit on the SDA or SCL lines specifically for the sensor connected to channel 4.

**Recommended Next Steps (Hardware Troubleshooting):**

1.  **Power Down:** Turn off power to the Nano and sensors.
2.  **Inspect Wiring:** Carefully re-inspect the VCC, GND, SDA, and SCL connections for the sensor plugged into the multiplexer's channel 4 port. Ensure they are secure and not shorting against anything.
3.  **Swap Sensors:** The best test is to **swap** the physical sensor currently connected to channel 4 with a sensor from another channel that you know was working correctly (e.g., swap the sensors connected to channel 3 and channel 4).
4.  **Power Up and Test:** Turn the power back on and run the code again.
    *   **If the freeze now happens when trying to read channel 3:** This strongly indicates the sensor *originally* on channel 4 is faulty.
    *   **If the freeze *still* happens when trying to read channel 4 (even with the known good sensor):** This suggests a problem with the multiplexer's channel 4 port itself, or the wiring *between* the multiplexer and the Nano related to that channel (less likely if other channels work fine).

**Temporary Code Workaround (If needed):**

If you want to get the other sensors running while you troubleshoot the hardware, I can modify the code to completely skip trying to read channel 4. Let me know if you'd like to do that.

**Run this refactored code.** Observe the debug output carefully:

*   Does it complete the VL53L0X section and then freeze during the subsequent VL53L5CX loop (e.g., at the `isDataReady()` call for channel 0, or whichever VL53L5CX is first)? This would suggest the VL53L0X interaction leaves the I2C bus or multiplexer in a bad state.

// filepath: /Users/justin/Library/CloudStorage/Dropbox/NYU/Semester 2 ('25 Spring)/Sinetactophone/daisyduino/src/nano/main.cpp
void loop() {
  Serial.println("--- Loop Start ---"); // Debug: Confirm loop is running

  // --- Revised Loop Structure ---
  VL53L5CX_ResultsData allSensorData[MAX_SENSORS]; // Array to hold data for all sensors
  bool sensorReadOK[MAX_SENSORS] = {false}; // Track successful reads in this loop iteration
  int vl53l0xReading = -1; // Store VL53L0X reading, -1 indicates error/no reading
  bool vl53l0xReadOK = false; // Track successful read for VL53L0X

  // 1. Read data from all configured sensors and store it
  // Serial.println("Debug: Starting sensor read pass..."); // Optional Debug
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    // --- Special Read for VL53L0X ---
    if (i == VL53L0X_CHANNEL && vl53l0xConfigured) {
      Serial.print("Debug: Attempting read from VL53L0X (Channel "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(")"); // Debug
      selectChannel(VL53L0X_CHANNEL);
      delay(1);
      VL53L0X_RangingMeasurementData_t measure;
      lox.rangingTest(&measure, false); // false = do not print debug info

      if (measure.RangeStatus != 4) {  // status 4 means out of range
        vl53l0xReading = measure.RangeMilliMeter;
        vl53l0xReadOK = true;
        Serial.println("Debug: VL53L0X read OK."); // Debug
      } else {
        vl53l0xReading = -1;
        vl53l0xReadOK = false;
        Serial.println("Debug: VL53L0X read failed or out of range."); // Debug
      }
      continue;
    }
    // --- End Special Read for VL53L0X ---

    // Read VL53L5CX sensors
    if (sensorConfigured[i]) {
      Serial.print("Debug: Attempting read from VL53L5CX (Channel "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(")"); // Debug
      uint8_t channel = i;
      selectChannel(channel);
      Serial.print("Debug: selectChannel("); Serial.print(channel); Serial.println(") completed."); // Debug: Confirm selectChannel returns
      delay(1);
      Serial.print("Debug: Calling isDataReady() for channel "); Serial.println(i); // Debug: Add this line
      if (myImagers[i].isDataReady()) {
        Serial.print("Debug: VL53L5CX data ready for channel "); Serial.println(i); // Debug
        if (myImagers[i].getRangingData(&allSensorData[i])) {
          sensorReadOK[i] = true;
          Serial.print("Debug: VL53L5CX getRangingData OK for channel "); Serial.println(i); // Debug
        } else {
          sensorReadOK[i] = false;
          Serial.print("!ERR: Sensor slot "); Serial.print(i); Serial.println(" getRangingData failed");
        }
      } else {
         sensorReadOK[i] = false;
         Serial.print("Debug: VL53L5CX data NOT ready for channel "); Serial.println(i); // Debug
      }
    } else {
        // This case means sensorConfigured[i] is false
        sensorReadOK[i] = false;
        // Optional: Add a debug print here if you want to see unconfigured sensors being skipped
        // if (i != VL53L0X_CHANNEL) { // Avoid printing for the L0X channel slot if it wasn't configured
        //    Serial.print("Debug: Skipping unconfigured VL53L5CX slot "); Serial.println(i);
        // }
    }
  }
  // Serial.println("Debug: Finished sensor read pass."); // Optional Debug

  // 2. Print the stored data
  // Serial.println("Debug: Starting print pass..."); // Optional Debug

  // Print VL53L5CX data: one line per zone reading
  for (int i = 0; i < MAX_SENSORS; i++) {
    if (i == VL53L0X_CHANNEL) continue;

    if (sensorConfigured[i] && sensorReadOK[i]) {
      // Serial.print("Debug: Printing VL53L5CX data for channel "); Serial.println(i); // Debug (can be noisy)
      for (int j = 0; j < SENSOR_RESOLUTION; j++) {
        Serial.print(">s");
        Serial.print(i);
        Serial.print("z");
        Serial.print(j);
        Serial.print(":");
        Serial.println(allSensorData[i].distance_mm[j]);
      }
    } else if (sensorConfigured[i] && !sensorReadOK[i]) {
        // Debug: Indicate if a configured sensor failed the read check for printing
    }
  }

  // Print VL53L0X data separately
  if (vl53l0xConfigured && vl53l0xReadOK) {
    Serial.println("Debug: Printing VL53L0X data."); // Debug
    Serial.print(">s");
    Serial.print(VL53L0X_CHANNEL);
    Serial.print("_dist:");
    Serial.println(vl53l0xReading);
  } else if (vl53l0xConfigured && !vl53l0xReadOK) {}

  Serial.println("--- Loop End ---"); // Debug: Confirm loop end is reached
  // No delay at the end of the loop
}
